texts.es: Rosa tiene 34 años, vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos en su propia casa. Ella tiene su propia fábrica de ladrillos la cual adquirió hace 2 años, por herencia de sus padres, hoy en día trabaja durante todo el día junto con su esposo, el cual fábrica los ladrillos, ayudado por varios peones que contrataron para agilizar su producción, en promedio en cada quincena, ellos pueden elaborar hasta  25 millares de ladrillos los cuales son vendidos a los compradores, los cuales acuden a su fábrica porque ya conocen de la calidad de ladrillos que se ofrecen, ahora ella esta esperando, alcanzar niveles de ventas mas altos, lo cual se da generalmente en épocas de verano, queriendo más adelante patentar sus ladrillos y poder adquirir nuevos terrenos de tierra arcillosa para poder seguir produciéndolos. Es la primera vez que Rosa tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella es una de las fundadoras de su banco comunal y actualmente forma parte de la junta directiva, ella se compromete en realizar un trabajo honrado y digno. El dinero solicitando es para invertir en la compra de más extensiones de terrenos, para lo cual el préstamo solo cubre la tercera parte de su precio, completando el resto con sus propios ahorros.
texts.en:
Rosa is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two children in their own home. She has a brick-making factory that she acquired two years ago from her parents. Now she works there every day, along with her husband, who makes the bricks. They are helped by several contract workers in order to increase production. On average, every 15 days they make 25,000 bricks to sell. Their customers come to the factory because they know the bricks are good-quality. Rosa is hoping to reach higher levels of sales, which usually happens during the summer. In the future she would like to patent her bricks and buy more land that has clay in it in order to continue making bricks. This is her first loan with MFP. She is one of the founding members of her community bank and today is part of the Director’s Committee and is committed to doing an honorable and dignified job. She will invest the money in more land—the loan will cover 1/3 of the cost and she will pay the rest with her savings.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase land to make bricks

loans.name: Erwin Julio

texts.es:
El Sr. Erwin Julio Zúñiga vive en el barrio Mira Flores del Torno, en el departamento de Santa Cruz, Bolivia, vive conjuntamente a sus padres en la casa de su padre. Se dedica al comercio de ganado porcino, es un cliente antiguo que empezó a trabajar con nosotros hace desde el 2006.
Además de esto tiene como profesión la de Médico Veterinario con lo que se ayuda mucho para el comercio de ganado. El crédito que le fue desembolsado es especialmente para la compra de ganado porcino, que comercializará en la ciudad de Santa Cruz, Bolivia. Es un muy buen cliente tiene muchas ganas de seguir trabajando con nuestra institución.
texts.en:
Mr. Erwin Julio Zúñiga lives with his parents in the Mira Flores del Torno neighborhood in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. He makes a living raising pigs. He has been a client [of Emprender, the loan agency] since 2006. In addition, he also acts as a veterinarian, which helps a lot when raising and selling animals. The loan he received is for buying more pigs, which he sells in the city of Santa Cruz. He is a good loan client who really wants to keep working with [Emprender].

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pigs

loans.name: Custodio

texts.es:
El Sr. Custodio vive desde hace 14 años en la localidad de Pampa Coscal, en las afueras del municipio de El Torno en el Departamento de Santa Cruz, en este lugar es dueño de una pequeña parcela en la cual realiza su actividad de agricultura, especializandosé en frijoles y maíz.
Cuenta con casa propia en la que vive con su esposa y sus 7 hijos. El crédito que el Sr. Solicita será justamente para aumentar su capital, y seguir con la siembra de poroto y maíz que es la fuente principal de sus ingresos con la que mantiene a toda su familia. Su objetivo es el de llegar a ser un productor de mayor capital y hacer la entrega de sus productos directamente a los mercados centrales de Santa Cruz.
texts.en:
Custodio has lived in the Pampa Coscal neighborhood for the past 14 years. His lives on the outskirts of El Torno in Santa Cruz, Bolivia. He owns a small plot of land where he works as a farmer, specializing in beans and corn. He has his own home that he shares with his wife and their 7 children. The loan he is asking for will be used to increase his capital and continue planting kidney beans and corn—this is the main source of income for his entire family. His goal is to become a farmer with more capital and deliver his products directly to the main markets in Santa Cruz.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plant corn and beans

loans.name: Esteban

texts.es: El Sr. Damian L. F. se dedica al comercio de Cd´s y DVD´s. Que vende en su pequeña tienda ubicada en la calle Figueroa un lugar bastante conocido en la ciudad de La Paz para el comercio de CD's y películas en DVD, también lleva gran parte de su mercaderia al departamento de Oruro. Actividad con la que mantiene a su familia de cinco integrantes sus tres hijos aún estudian en la escuela siendo este negocio el unico que tiene para dotar de ingresos a su familiaes por eso que se beneficia con el Financiamiento por parte de KIVA. En su tiempo con la institución ha demostrado calidez humana y mucha responsabilidad.
texts.en:
Mr. Damian L. F. earns a living by selling CDs and DVDs.. He has a small store on Figueroa street in a well-known place in the city of La Paz. He also travels to the state of Oruro to sell his merchandise. His job helps him support his family—his three children are still in school so this is the only income they have to live on. This is why he will benefit from the loan from Kiva. In his time working with [Emprender] he has shown kindness and responsibility.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy DVDs

loans.name: Preciosa

texts.en:
Mrs. Preciosa S., 60, lives in Antipolo, Dapitan City. She is a widow who has managed to raise her four children alone. This was a very difficult task, but she struggled to survive for the sake of her children.

She patiently looked for an institution that could help her. When she learned about Paglaum MPC, she wasted no time, and she became a member on May 29, 2008. She used her first loan of 3,000 PHP to buy two piglets and this is how she started her hog-raising business. She is grateful to God that, with the help of her children, her hog-raising business has done very well and she has buyers from many different places. Now she is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy feed feed and vitamins for her hogs. She hopes to make a concrete piggery for her pigs. She will continue using Paglaum MPC, because this organization really helps to improve the lives of the landless.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs

loans.name: Rizalina

texts.en: Mrs. Rizalina V. lives in Balintawak, Pagadian City, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 52 years old and has five children who are all married. Presently, she has two grandchildren who live with her as her dependents.  Her husband is a motorcycle driver. She has a snack business that she began with her first loan of Php 1,000.00. She is now applying for a loan of Php 8,000.00 so she can purchase additional sugar, flour, yeast, and kitchen utensils, which she needs for cooking “binoulos” (a Filipino snack delicacy). She also wants to cook “bibingka” (another Filipino snack delicacy). She hopes to make enough money to build a concrete house and to buy a motorcycle that she can use to deliver her products to different school canteens in the nearest "barangays" (Filipino settlements or barrios). In addition, she would like to generate enough work to hire her unemployed neighbor.

loans.use: Buy additional ingredients for snack vending

loans.name: Debbie

texts.en:
A responsible lady best describes Debbie B., 41 years old, single and resident of Dullan, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She helps her family since her mother died. Her mother was a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) before she died. But because of her lingering sickness, Debbie's mother couldn't attend the weekly meetings of PMPC; she then transferred her membership to Debbie.

Debbie engaged herself in “sari-sari store" (a small grocery) business where she could earn a living. The financial assistance that the PMPC provided to Debbie has helped her a lot. Being a member in good standing, she was able to avail of  loans several times already. Now, she applies for PHP14,900 for coconut trading. She plans also to buy dried fish in Pagadian City for sale. In the future, she also hopes that someday she will also have her own family.

loans.use: To buy coconuts for sale

loans.name: Fe

texts.en: Hard-working woman best describes Mrs. Fe. I., 40 years old, separated, and a resident of Talairon, Misamis Occidental. She has three children, one in college and two in high school. Twelve years has passed since she has been separated from her husband. She works hard to raise her three children. With the help of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, she was able to start-up a “sari-sari” store (small grocery store) with an initial capital of PHP 3,000. It all started with "one"-- one bottle of edible oil, vinegar, soy sauce, etc. She has managed it well. Until now, the business has existed. Now, she is requesting a loan of PHP 10,000 to buy longaniza to sell. Her other source of income is through the selling of AVON and SME products. She will be happy and fulfilled if she sees all her children finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy longaniza to sell

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
Mrs. Maribel G., 41, married to Danilo, a farmern, is blessed with one son. Presently, she is residing at Napilan, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She was recognized as member of PDP-LP, the micro-finance Program of Paglaum last April 28, 2006. She is presently operating a small sari-sari (variety) store located at their residence. She started it through her first loan from the Cooperative amounting to PHP 2,500.

In  two years of being a PMPC member she learned how to manage a small business, save money and attended various training activities. She is very thankful to PMPC for the programs and services that help her a lot. She is now on her 7th loan amounting to  PHP 14,500.00 to be used as additional capital of  her sari-sari store.  She will purchase additional grocery items such as canned goods, rice, condiments and many others. She plans to expand her business to become a mini grocery someday. 

Her greatest ambition in life is be able to let her son finish college and have a decent home for the family.

loans.use: Additional Grocery Items for sale

loans.name: Omar Augusto

texts.es:
El señor Omar Augusto Domínguez y su esposa la señora Katy Salas tienen dos hijos para los cuales quieren lo mejor.
A la vivienda le esta haciendo falta la barda alrededor de ella pero por el momento no cuentan con el dinero necesario para comprar el material ya que Don Omar Augusto trabaja en la construcción y en horas adiciones realizar la mejora. Es por eso  que están solicitando un crédito, ya que están preocupados cunado los  niños salen a jugar no tienen seguridad. Planean pagar este préstamo con el ingreso que generan de su trabajo,
(En la foto apareces la esposa la señora Katy Salas ya que el señor Omar Augusto se encontraba en su trabajo)
texts.en:
Omar Augusto Domínguez and his wife, Katy Salas, have two children whom they love more than anything. Their home is missing a fence around it, but at the moment they don't have the necessary funds to purchase the materials. Omar works in construction and in his spare time he plans to make the improvements. It's for this reason they are requesting a loan, since they worry for their children's security when they go out and play. They plan to repay the loan with income from Omar's job. (Katy is in the photo because Omar was at work when it was taken)

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a fence around home

loans.name: Apu Katunki Group

texts.es:
Este banco se denomina, "APU KATUNKI", en lengua quechua, responde el nombre a una deidad en el tiempo de los inkas, se encuentra situado en la ciudad del Cusco, pero nuestros 14 socios son un grupo de vecinos del distrito de puka pukara, lugar dónde ellos se dedican desde hace 15 años a la elaboración y venta de artesanías artesanales típicas de la zona del Cusco; Este banco lo conforman 10 socias mujeres y 04 socios varones.

Estos socios están sumamente agradecidos con el apoyo que recibirán, puesto que por ser artesanos ellos no reciben mayor facilidad de la banca financiera; hoy ellos valoran el apoyo brindado mediante este medio, por lo que les permitirá comprar y realizar sus productos con mejor calidad y así continuar con la labor que les fuera heredada desde el tiempo de sus antepasados y poder plasmar la cultura.

Los socios se comprometen en devolver el préstamo en la fecha designada y a trabajr mucho para cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
The community bank is named “Apu Katunki,” a name in the quechua language that corresponds with a god of the inkas. The bank is located in the city of Cusco, but this group of 14 members is a group of neighbors from the puka pukara district. For the past 15 years they have made and sold typical regional handicrafts. The group is made up of 10 women and 4 men. These members are very grateful for the help they will receive—because they are artisans it is hard to receive support from financial institutions. They value the help available through [Kiva], because it will help them make better-quality products. They inherited this work from their ancestors to help shape and mold their culture. The members are dedicated to repaying the loan by the date indicated and to work hard in order to achieve their goals.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clay and other materials to make crafts

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: A 23-year-old, Marivic Buhi-an is married to her husband who is a teacher. They have one child and reside in Balangasan, Pagadian City, Zamboanga Del Sur. Marivic also supports her parents, especially with their basic needs. Her parents guide her on how to ensure that the piglets she raises grow healthy. Marivic applied for a loan worth PHP 5,000 payable in six months, for purchasing feeds and more piglets. Three months after raising the piglets, Marivic butchers the pigs and sells them per kilo. She hopes that someday the piggery business will flourish and hopefully provide supply to the neighboring towns. Aside from that, Marivic and her husband can prepare for the education of their child.

loans.use: To expand her pig raising business

loans.name: Sandra Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Sandra Patricia C. es madre soltera y tiene bajo su responsabilidad ha dos hijos que actual mente están estudian y quiere lo mejor para ellos.
A la vivienda le está haciendo falta la barda, pero en este momento no cuenta con el capital necesario para comprar el material y pagar la mano de obra. Es por eso que solicita un préstamo para poder realizar la mejora y así darles la seguridad a sus hijos ya que ella trabaja casi todo el día en una fabrica en el departamento de producción. Planea pagar esté crédito con los ingresos de su empleo.
texts.en:
Ms. Sandra Patricia C. is a single mother of 2 children. Her children are still in school and she wants the best for them. At her home, the only thing missing is a wall in front of the house. At this time she does not have the money to buy the materials and pay for the work. That’s why she is asking for a loan to complete the home improvement project and provide security for her children. She works almost all day in the production department of a factory and she plans on paying back the loan with the income from her job.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Building a wall in front of her home

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia V., 58, is presently residing in Brgy. Balintawak, Pagadian City, Zamboanga Del Sur.  She used to be a widow with 9 children, all of whom are married.  She got  married again to a retired teacher, with whom she has 1 child, who still studying.  Their major source of income comes from the rental of passenger motorcycl, driven by her son-in-law.

Mrs. V. also has existing sari-sari (variety) store for 30 years.  She is a member of Paglaum Cooperative for 10 months and she is already on her second loan.  She applied loan worth Php 8,000 for purchasing additional  detergent soap, powder soap, 10 cases of different soft drinks and 5 different candies for her store.  She has existing capital of P2,000, including her store inventory.  She plans to expand her business into snack vending for additional income to prepare for her daughter's college education.  Aside from that she also dreams to purchase a residential house in sub-division someday came from the profit of her business.

loans.use: to expand her sari sari (variety) store business

loans.name: Manolita

texts.en:
Mrs. Manolita Q. is 65 years old. She is married and lives in Lobogon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She has 3 children. Her husband is a farmer.

For her age, Mrs. Manolita is still very active; she still works to earn a living. She is a very good cook, especially when it comes to making “puto” (bread made of ground rice) and home-made cookies. It is her skill.

Additionally, she is now trying to raise pigs, a new venture. Fortunately, so far, this has been successful. She has already sold some of her pigs.

Manolita joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative to gain access to financial assistance and take advantage of the benefits that members get. She initially received start-up capital of only PHP 3,000. Now, she is applying for a loan of PHP 14,900 so she can buy fertilizers for her new farm. She would like to harvest more rice so she can compensate for her expenses.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers for rice production

loans.name: Carlita

texts.en:
Mrs. Carlita C., 67 years old, is a widow. She lives in Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental.

Carlita is a very industrious woman and is popular with her neighbors. She plays the role of a mother and a father at the same time for her family.

She primarily earns a living buying and selling coconuts. It is a very important business. With the profits from her business, she is able to feed her children and meet their daily consumption needs. She also raises pigs.

Joining Paglaum Cooperative really helped Carlita solve her financial problems. She also joined so she could benefit from its other resources, such as insurance. The assurance that her family gets from Paglaum MPC, is very important to her.

She has now applied for a loan of PHP 14,900 so she can buy sacks of food to feed her pigs. She has 3 piglets, which she is raising in addition to her main business. In the future, she looks forward to a comfortable life. She wants to have her own piggery one day.

loans.use: To buy food for her pigs

loans.name: Jovy

texts.en: A very young woman best describes Jovy L., 23 years old, married, and living at Buenavista, Oroquieta City. She has two children. Her husband is a mere laborer. At a young age, Jovy already knew that life is not that easy! She tried her best to provide for the needs of her family; that’s why she engaged herself in charcoal making and selling, appearing dirty physically, but earning sufficiently. In order to have enough capital, she joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative in October 2007 and was able to start her business. Jovy has already availed other loans several times. Now, she is requesting a loan of PHP 14,900 to buy coconut shells to be processed into charcoal. In the future, she wants to buy a motorcycle to be used as transportation to go to and from the market. Jovy will be fulfilled as a parent if all her children will finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy coconut shells for charcoal production

loans.name: Florepes

texts.en: Mrs. Florepes C., 38, married and lives in Lumbayao, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She has 5 children. Her husband is a mere laborer. In order to help her husband, she decided to join Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) last April 2004. She availed loan for PHP3,000 and used it as initial capital for her “sari-sari” store (small grocery store). She was able to manage the business successfully; in fact, it became the source of their daily consumption needs and also for allowances of her elementary children in school. Now, she applies for PHP14,900 to buy piglets and feeds for her duck. She ventures into this new business to have also additional source of income. Someday, she plans to buy RTW’s (Ready to wear) products from Cebu. She will be happy enough if she sees all her children finish their studies.

loans.use: To buy piglet & feeds for duck raising

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.en:
Beatriz is a simple entrepreneur selling vegetables and poultry animals such as chickens and ducks.  She also raises hogs and she personally feed them and clean their pig pen.  

Beatriz shared all her sacrifices in the business for the welfare of her family.  Due to lack of capital, she wants to avail loan amounting to PHP6,000 to further improve her business so that she can support her family and send her children to school since there were times when her income is not enough to provide them with their educational needs. She intends to use the loan to buy another piglet that she can sell afterwards.  She is hoping that she can sustain all her ventures by simply working hard and managing her time wisely so she will never waste every opportunity that comes. 

She was married to Allan, a farmer and they are blessed with four children: Divina-15 years old, high school student; Bernadeth-14 years old, also in high school; Jonathan - 12 years old, elementary student and Adrian, 3 years old. Through their small enterprise, Beatriz and her husband are helping each another to somehow uplift their poor living condition.

loans.use: To buy additional piglets for fattening

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia E. is 24 years old and married to Frederick, a ferryboat operator. They have a four year old son named John Gerald. The couple is helping one another in providing the daily needs of their family and saves some of their income in preparation of their son’s education.  

Their sole source of income is their ferry boat that transport passengers from their village to the town proper of Ilagan crossing the Cagayan River.  Nelia supported her husband in their business and for now she is asking for financial support to the lenders amounting to PHP4,000.  The loan will be used to repair their boat and hopefully start in the vending business of snacks or vegetables for them to have an increase in income.  She hopes to pursue her business plans and ambitions for her family especially for their child’s future.

loans.use: Boat repair

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites T. and her family are living in Barangay Lulutan, Ilagan, Isabela.  She and her husband are blessed with a son named Marvin who is now six months old.  She is in the direct selling business while her husband is working as a ferry boat operator in their village and sometimes a farmer for additional income.  

Most of her products are Tupperware and other plastic ware.  To further support her business, she is now asking for a loan of PHP4,000.  This amount will not only be used for her direct selling business but also to repair their boat that they are using for transporting their passengers.  She came up with this kind of business because there are times when she and her husband argue because they lack financially.  Now that she had her own business, somehow their income meets the needs of their family.  

“There is no harm in trying” said Marites.  She hopes that someday she will able to contribute towards the progress of their family through her hard works and patience in overcoming difficulties of life.

loans.use: Additional capital and for boat repair

loans.name: Anabella

texts.en:
Anabella D. sells different merchandise such as vegetables and rice.  She wishes to avail a loan of PHP 4,000 so that she can purchase additional products that she can sell in their village like processed meat, rice, and vegetables.  She does not want to lose hope and she is willing to face all the problems that may come along for the sake of her children.  "I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me always," says Anabella.  Through the help of the lenders, she is positive that she can have a progressive business someday.

Anabella is a widow with four children: Rodel, 28, a soldier,  Anabella, 24, high school graduate and working as a service crew in Manila, Nelia, 21, still studying in college and Rodolfo, 16, a graduating high school student. Anabella is doing her best to send her two children to school with the help of her eldest son.

loans.use: To purchase rice and vegetables

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa A.,48, wife of Elito, and a mother of five children.  Her five children are: Raffy, 25, and Myla, 22, are both high school undergraduates; Maribeth, 20, a graduate of caregiver course; Ryan, 15, a high school student and Jandell, the youngest is13 years old, graduating in the elementary level.  Her family is happily living together in Barangay San Lorenzo Ilagan, Isabela.

Elsa is managing her hog-raising business for years that became her major source of income to provide her children with school allowance and tuition fees.  Aside from hog-raising, her husband is also engaged in charcoal-making for added income that support their farming needs.  However, they still lack financially, thus, Elsa is requesting a loan of PHP5,000 for the feeds supply of their hogs.  She hopes that their businesses will grow for the benefit of their family.

Elsa remains humble and hard working for she believes that these traits will lead to achieve her goals in life.

loans.use: To buy feeds supply

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en:
Analyn D. is a vegetable vendor from the village of San Lorenzo in Ilagan, Isabela.  She is married to Freddie, a farmer of corn and vegetables, which she sells in their place.  They have two children: Jay-Ar, 21, a high school graduate and Venus, 16, a third year high school student.  They are living in a simple community quite far from the town proper.  

Analyn wants to avail a loan of PHP5,000 to support her vending business.  She plans to buy additional vegetable and to expand her rice retailing business to increase her income and help her husband in their farming needs.  She hopes that her loan request will be approved to sustain her enterprise so she can continue to send their youngest child to school.  

She is very eager to work hard to meet her goals and according to her, “time is gold” that she would not take things for granted so that she could be a successful entrepreneur someday.

loans.use: To buy additional vegetable and expand rice retailing business

loans.name: Adela

texts.en:
Adela is 24 years old and already married to Noel, a furniture maker.  They have a six year old son named Jericho and he is now in grade one studying in the public school located in their Barangay at San Lorenzo Ilagan, Isabela.
 
Her husband is managing and operating a furniture business in their house.  The business is not that big and progressive, they only have few customers since their business is not popular to other villages.  With this, Adela thought of seeking for financial assistance to support their furniture making and to make more designs and market their products.  She is now requesting at least PHP4,000 for expansion and she is also planning to start another business to help her husband earn additional income.
  	
Adela also shared that serving her family brings her happiness in her heart. In simple ways she shows her support and perseverance to be of help to her husband and child.

loans.use: Business Expansion

loans.name: Maribel

texts.en:
“Patience and hard work will someday provide good income”, says Maribel, a quotation that motivates her in the business.  

Maribel R. is a rice retailer in their village in Barangay Lullutan Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Roberto, a farmer and they have two children: Clenton -15 years old, elementary graduate and Jesus - 9 years old, elementary student. Poverty is their reason why they were not able to send their eldest to school and pursue his studies.  She said that she and her husband are striving hard to uplift their life from poverty in a way they can.  

Maribel wanted to avail a loan of PHP4,000 as business capital.  She will use the loan to purchase three sacks of rice that she sells in retail and hopefully increase her current monthly income of PHP1,000 (USD$21) which is really not enough to meet their needs.  She is glad that her husband is also earning something from their farm during harvest season.  She works hard in her business and save something for the high school education of their children.

loans.use: To purchase three sacks of rice

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina D. S. is from the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. She is married to Leoncio and they have five children; two of them are already college graduates and three are still studying. Despite the difficulties of life, the couple still manages to send their children to school and they are thankful that some of their children sometimes assist them with their needs.

Hog-raising is Marina's chosen business. With her wish to expand, she is now asking for a loan of PHP 7,000 that she can use to pursue her plan. The loan will not only assist her in improving her hog-raising business but also in sending her children to school and providing them with a school allowance and tuition fees. She also intends to use some of the loan to help her husband with their farming needs.

She believes that somehow, they will be able to overcome the trials and difficulties they are experiencing right now. Ignoring the hardship by working hard is better than doing nothing, Marina added.

loans.use: For her hog-raising and farming needs

loans.name: Baby Lou

texts.en:
Baby Lou is diligently looking for every opportunity that she can find for an alternative source of income. At present she is maintaining a hog-raising business and she can see that it has a big potential to become productive. For the improvement of her business, she would like to request at least PHP 5,000. She will use the loan to purchase feed for her hogs. She believes that she has a lot of things to do and for her “time is gold”, that she needs to make the most out of it for the welfare of her family.

She and her family are living in Barangay (township) San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. Her husband Raffy is a corn and rice farmer. The couple is blessed with one daughter named Ashley Faye, one year old.

loans.use: to buy feed for her pig raising

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
Piggery and farming are the sole sources of income of Olivia and her family. Her husband is in charge of managing their farm but he also helps her in maintaining her piggery. They have two children; Oliver, 13 years old, a high school student and Vincent, 11 years old and in the elementary level. The couple is working hard for the future of their children and for them to be free from poverty.

To able to restart her piggery business, Olivia wants to borrow a loan of PHP 4,000 to buy a piglet and feed. She believes that this business will grow and it will support the education of their two sons. Pig-raising has been her business ever since, however, it was stopped for a while due to lack of capital.

The couple is thankful for this opportunity for they believe that in this way, they can uplift their standard of living; they also pray for good health.

loans.use: To buy a piglet and feed

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily V. is from the village of Lullutan, Ilagan, Isabela. The place can only be reached by riding a ferry boat to cross the river. She is 40 years old and married to Camilo, the ferry boat operator in their place of residence. Their marriage was blessed with six children: Victorino - 23 years old; Richard - 22 years old; Gerome - 16 years old; Lea Mae - 14 years old; Shella Mae - 4 years old and Neil - 1 year old. Four of them are high school graduates.

Barbecue vending is Emily's business in their village. She can say that they have average living conditions at present. Even though they are both earning an income, still it is not enough to meet the growing needs of their family. Her loan request of PHP 4,000 will greatly help her in the business. Emily is planning to buy additional products to sell such as snacks and boiled eggs once the loan is granted.

Emily is hoping that all her children will able to pursue their studies. She and her husband will work hard for them to have a better future.

loans.use: Additional products to sell

loans.name: Virgin

texts.en:
Virgin G. is already a widow. She was left with two children: Alpha – 22 years old, a high school graduate and Virnhood – 20 years old, a college student. Sending her younger child to school is very costly; she is thankful that her elder daughter is helping financially in providing her with educational needs, for she cannot do it alone. They are living in Barangay (township) Villa Gamiao, San Mateo, Isabela.

To support her children, Virgin is engaged in the hog-raising business. Due to limited capital, she is now asking for financial support amounting to PHP 4,000. The loan will be used to sustain her business and to buy feed and vaccines for her hogs to be free from diseases. Through the business, she is able to provide the basic needs of her family and somehow afford to send her daughter to school. She further said that “there’s nothing wrong in trying; what is wrong is when you have not even tried things you wanted to try”.

loans.use: To buy feed and medicines for her hogs

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Pacita is in the "rolling store" business. She sells different types of vegetables and snacks whereby she generates a weekly income of PHP 1,500 that she budgets as rolling capital and utilizes to support her family and educate her two younger children. According to her, she needs to double her income to further support the needs of her family since her current income is not enough. She is now requesting to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 that will served as additional capital for her vending business. She hopes that through her business and efforts, her children will earn a college diploma.

She and her family are living in Villa Gamiao, San Mateo, Isabela. She is 53 years old, married to Amor Mario with six children: the eldest is Jonalyn - 25 years old, an elementary graduate; Melissa - 22 years old, a high school graduate; Ernie - 20 years old, also a high school graduate; Jo-an - 18 years old, an elementary graduate; Erwin - 16 years old still studying; and the youngest who is May-an - 11 years old, an elementary student.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is a simple entrepreneur, hoping for a progressive life for her family. She manages a rice vending business in their village as her source of income. She is married to Jerwin, and their daughter Lea is now three years old.

She has wanted to request a loan of PHP 4,000 to support her rice vending business for almost one year. She intends to use the loan to purchase at least two sacks of rice that she will sell at retail prices. Her business generates a weekly income of PHP 1,200 and she budgets it for their immediate needs and as rolling capital. To achieve her business goals, Catherine said that she must work hard and always be humble and patient.

loans.use: To  buy two sacks of rice

loans.name: Analyn

texts.en: Analyn is a single entrepreneur. She is a direct dealer of beauty products for men and women. Other than that, she is also engaged in the poultry business, raising ducks and chickens.  She is proud that she can help her family earn something for their daily needs.  Thus, to further maintain her business activities, Analyn wants to take out a loan amounting to PHP 4,000.  She believes that this amount will help her family be lifted out of poverty.  She hopes that her loan will be granted so that she will be able to improve her business and somehow expand to other types of business someday.  It is just a matter of “sacrifice,” says Analyn.

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Pepita

texts.en:
Pepita owns and manages a sari-sari store (a community-based business) in their village. Aside from it, she also maintains a hog-raising business as their additional source of income.  Through the businesses she manages, Pepita is able to assist her husband in providing their farming needs. To both improve her store and hog-raising enterprise, Pepita wants to take out a loan amounting to PHP 9,000 for added capital. “Be patient and always aim high for a better life,” she ended. 

Pepita is married to Juanito and they are living in Barangay (township) Villa Gamiao in San Mateo, Isabela.  They have six children: Juanito Jr. - 38 years old, a high school graduate; Rey - 36 years old, an elementary graduate; Donalyn - 34 years old, college level; Ruben - 31 years old, an elementary graduate; Joerge - 28 years old, college level; and Daisy - 26 years old, college level, now working as a domestic helper abroad.

loans.use: additonal capital

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina, 52 years old and married to Efrenand, has four children. Her husband is working as a farmer like most of the residents of their village, since farming is the major source of livelihood there. Their children are: Analyn - 29 years old, a graduate of a computer secretarial course; Alberto - 26 years old, working as a machine operator in Manila; Noel - 25 years old, a college graduate; and Joel - 23 years old. Her children are her treasure in life, however, she feels sad because she was not able to provide all of them with a better education.

Hog-raising is her choice of business. This has been her way of helping her husband provide their financial needs. She dreams of becoming successful in the business. This has motivated her to request a loan of PHP 5,000 that she will use to purchase piglets, feed, and medicines for her hogs. She believes that the improvement of her business also depends on hard work and perseverance.

loans.use: To purchase piglets and feed

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 34 years old and married to Salvador L., Jr. The couple was blessed with three children: Julius Jay -11 years old; Victoria Pearl - 9 years old, both in the elementary level, and the youngest is Jiabeth - 4 years old. The family lives in Barangay (township) Villa Gamiao, a simple village in San Mateo, Isabela.

Betty manages a "rolling store" in their village that offers different types of goods to earn money for their children and for their daily needs. Aside from that, she also sells native cakes and other foods for snacks. From her business, she is able to earn an average weekly income of PHP 1,000 that she budgets for her family and as rolling capital. She is planning to put up a mini-restaurant in their place for added income.

With this, she is requesting a loan of PHP 5,000 for the development and improvement of her store. Some of her loan will also be used to repair her bicycle that she uses in her rolling business; it needs repair so she can avoid accidents. According to her, patience and love of the business are essential to every entrepreneur like her in order to succeed.

loans.use: store improvement

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia is 40 years old and married to Bernardo, a farmer. Their marriage was blessed with five children: Gelord - 17 years old, fourth year high school; John Paul -14 years old, second year high school; Joanne Joy -12 years old, first year high school; Jayby - 9 years old; and the youngest is Jeramay - 2 years old. Her family lives together in the village of Villa Gamiao San Mateo, Isabela. She says that they are happy despite the difficulties that they are going through in life.

Sonia is in the vending and poultry business in their village. She used to raise native chickens to cater for the daily school allowance of her children. Due to limited capital, she is now in need of financial assistance of PHP 4,000 to restore her vending business. She is planning to buy some ingredients like fish paste, onions, garlic, glutinous rice, and other spices needed in her snack vending business. With the support of her husband, together they work hard for the improvement of their living conditions. Sonia hopes that her loan request will be granted because “If you persevere on the things you are doing, you’ll be blessed beyond your expectations,” shares Sonia.

loans.use: To restore her vending business

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine has been a vendor in the public school in their village for almost six years. She wants to have more products to sell in their school canteen; that is why she wants to take out a loan amounting to 4,000. For her, love of the business and cooperation from her family is helping her to achieve business development.

She is married to Reynaldo and blessed with four children. The eldest is Arnoldber -22 years old, a high school graduate, followed by Arnel - 20 years old, working as electrician in Manila; Rachel Joy -18 years old still studying, taking up criminology; and the youngest is Rea Jocel - 13 years old and a high school student.

loans.use: additional products to sell

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita, 46 years old, is married to Rene and the mother of four children: Remelyn - 15 years old, second year high school; Queenie - 13 years old, first year high school; Cecille - 12 years old, elementary graduate; and the youngest is Madelyn - 4 years old. They live in Villa Gamiao of San Mateo, Isabela where agriculture is their primary source of income.

Julita is engaged in the vending business. But aside from that, she also maintains a chicken and duck-raising business. To achieve her dream of having a well-developed business in the future, Julita wants to request a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 to fulfill her business plans. She said that she needs to be more patient and hard-working to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.en:
Eduardo is a responsible husband to Donata and a good father to their two children: Edonna, 20 years old and a college student, and Edmund, 19 years old, a high school graduate. Their younger child is helping his father in the farm since he was not able to pursue his college studies due to financial difficulties.

Eduardo is engaged in raising chickens and is also a farmer. With lack of capital, he is now asking for a loan of PHP 4,000 that he can use in the business. They are hoping that through his business, he can provide the immediate needs of his family and cater for the education of their daughter.

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
“Patience is the key to success,” says Leonida, a vendor of native delicacies in Villa Gamiao, San Mateo, Isabela. According to Leonida, her vending business will pave the way to progress and improvement of their poor living conditions, thus she wantes to borrow 5,000 pesos as vending capital. Her sacrifice in the business is for the future of her children.

Leonida is 39 years old, married to Juanito, a farmer in their village. They have four children: Cherry - 19 years old and a college student taking up computer secretarial; Caycelyn -16 years old, fourth year high school; followed by Lea - 11 years old and in grade six; and the youngest is Allysa - 5 years old and in day care.

loans.use: business capital

loans.name: Anabel Angélica

texts.es: Anabel Angélica G. R., reside en Tacuba departamento de Ahuachapán. A sus 39 años de edad se destaca por ser una mujer muy honrada y trabajadora, ya que ha creado un negocio en el cuál se encarga de hacer pasteles, ya sea para cumpleaños, bodas o cualquier otra celebración. A pesar que tiene una venta aceptable, Anabel solícita un préstamo a través del cual pueda obtener el capital necesario para poder invertir en su negocio y de esta manera incrementar sus ventas. El deseo más grande de Anabel es brindarles una mejor vida a sus pequeños hijos ya que ellos son el principal motor que la incentiva a trabajar duro para que de esta manera, pueda brindarles educación y un mejor futuro.
texts.en:
Anabel lives in the Tacaba region of Ahuachapan, El Salvador. At 39, she is known as an honorable and hard-working woman. She has created a cake-making business and makes cakes for birthdays, weddings or any other special occasion. Even though she is selling an acceptable amount, Anabel is asking for a loan in order to invest in her business and increase her sales. Anabel’s greatest wish is to provide her small children a better life—they are her main motivation behind her hard work. She would like to give them a good education and a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: ingredients for cake-making

loans.name: Tujisaidie Group

texts.en:
Mwantab has been a juice and bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items (eg. juice) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Mwantab is 24 years old, married, and has two children: ages 6 years and 6 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members: Rahma, Sada, Amina and Dalila. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more items (eg. juice) for her business.

loans.name: Tujisaidie Group

texts.en:
Fatma has been a juice and bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $50. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her stock for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money.

Fatma is 21 years old and single. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Salama, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To increase her stock by buying more items for her business.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam has been a bread and soup seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 8 years. She belongs to Wapendanao Group (Group code 2069). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 175. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more bread and meat for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Mariam is 38 years old, married, and has three children: ages 11, 8 and 7.

loans.use: To buy more bread and meat for her business.

loans.name: Sikudhani

texts.en:
Sikudhani has been a juice and bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 4 years. She belongs to Jitahidi Group (Group code 2014). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 195. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can increase her inventory by adding more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business and save money for future use.

Sikudhani is 33 years old, married, and has four children: ages 18, 12, 10 and 4.

loans.use: To increase her inventory by adding more items for her busness

loans.name: Msimamo Group

texts.en:
Nali has owned a small shop in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for nine years; working 14 hours per day, she currently earns an average monthly profit of $90. Nali is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business, hoping to thereby increase her profit and expand her business, save money for future use and pay her children’s school fees.

Nali, 38 years old, is married, and has four children aged 13, 12, 10 and 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member Sifat, who also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more items for her shop.

loans.name: Tujisaidie Group

texts.en:
A clothing and bites seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for the past four years, Riziki works at her business for 16 hours per day, currently earning an average monthly profit of $80. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to buy more clothes for her business, hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business, save money for future use and pay her children’s school fees.

Riziki, 46 years old, is divorced and has five children aged 20, 9, 6, 5 and 1. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Salma and Mwanakhamis, each of whom has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Kessi

texts.en:
Kessi owns a small shop  and has been a firewood seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 9 months. She belongs to Wachewaseme Group loan.  She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works at her business for 14 hours.  She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her shop and more firewood for re-sale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, and pay school fees for her youngest child.  

Kessi is 45  years old, divorced, and has four children: ages 28, 26, 24 and 9.

loans.use: To buy more items for her shop and more firewood for re-sale

loans.name: Tubadilike Group

texts.en:
Safia has been a clothing and juice seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothing and juice for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, and pay school fees for her children.

, Safia is 30 years old, married, and has four children: ages 13, 7, 3 and 5 months. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Mariam, who has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and juice for her business

loans.name: Mwanajuma's Group

texts.en:
Mwanajuma has been an egg seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She belongs to Tujisaidie Group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 80. Every day she works at her business for 13 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more eggs for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, and pay school fees for her child.

Mwanajuma is 35 years old, married, and has one child, age 8. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Salma, who has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more eggs for her business

loans.name: Khadija

texts.en:
Khadija has been a clothing seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 1 year. She belongs to Wapendanao Group. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 35. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours. She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, and pay school fees for her child when the time comes.

Khadija is 22 years old, married, and has one child.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business

loans.name: Hakuna Kulala Group

texts.en:
Mwaka has been a chips and porridge seller in the Mikunguni neighborhood of Zanzibar for 3 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 250.Every day she works at her business for 14 hours. She is requesting a loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items (Irish potatoes and flour) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business, save money for future use, and pay school fees for her children.

Mwaka is 35 years old, married, and has six children: ages 18, 16, 14, 12, 9 and 4. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Hayakuwa, Miza, Salama, and Salma. Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more food items (Irish potatoes and flour) for her business

loans.name: Elba

texts.es: Elba A. vive en Tacuba departamento de Ahuachapán, Elba vive con su esposo y dos hijas que están cursando la primaria. Elba se dedica  a la venta de ropa y cosméticos de manera ambulante sale todos los días temprano de su casa y ofrece su mercadería tocando de casa en casa, Elba sueña con darles una buena educación a su hijas ya que, ella y su esposo solo alcanzaron a llegar a la primaria, es por ello que esta mujer trabaja día a día para poder darles un futuro prometedor a sus hijas. Elba solicita un préstamo para adquirir variedad de mercadería y así tener más que ofrecer a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Elba A. lives in the Tacuba area of Ahuachapan, El Salvador. She lives with her husband and two daughters who are both in primary school. Elba sells clothes and cosmetics as a street vendor—she leaves her house early every day to offer her merchandise door-to-door. Since Elba and her husband only finished primary school, she dreams of giving her daughters a good education. Because she wants to provide her children with a promising future, she works hard every day. Elba is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise so she has more to offer to her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: expand merchandise of clothes and cosmetics

loans.name: Esmeralda De Jesús

texts.es: Esmeralda de Jesús G. vive en Zacatecoluca con su esposo y tres hijos. Por los múltiples gastos que representa tener tres hijos Esmeralda y su esposo se vieron en la necesidad de buscar otra  fuente de ingreso,  ya que no lograban cubrir gastos solo con el sueldo de su esposo;  así nació la idea de montar una tienda en la casa, donde Esmeralda podría trabajar y a su vez cuidar de sus pequeños hijos. Ahora Esmeralda solicita un crédito para invertir en su tienda y poder comprar productos de primera necesidad que los clientes demandan;  como gaseosas, sardinas y huevos. De esta manera Esmeralda lograra expandir su negocio y también sus ganancias puedan incrementar.
texts.en:
Esmeralda de Jesús G. lives in Zacatecoluca with her husband and three children. For the multiple expenses that three children represent, Esmeralda and her husband saw the need to find another source of income since they could not cover the expenses on his salary alone. This is how the idea to open a store in their home was born, which would allow Esmeralda to work and at the same time take care of her small children. Now, Esmeralda is requesting a loan to invest in her store and to be able to purchase products of basic necessity that the customers demand. These include soft drinks, sardines, and eggs. In this way, Esmeralda will achieve the expansion of her business and also her earnings will grow.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store.

loans.name: Mombasa Two Group

texts.en:
Mwatima has been a potato seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 2 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 90. Every day she works at her business for 7 hours. She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more potatoes for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mwatima is 30 years old, married, and has three children: ages 15, 9, and 5. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Maryam S., Mwanahamis and Maryam K..Each woman has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes for her business

loans.name: Mwajuma

texts.en:
Mwajuma has owned a small shop in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for many years. She belongs to Sisikwasisi Group (Group code 2042). She currently earns an average monthly profit of US$ 20.Every day she works at her business. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items to increase her stock for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Mwajuma is 38 years old, married, and has three children: ages 13, 9, and 8.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock

loans.name: Safi Nia Group

texts.en:
Wanu has been a firewood seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar for 5 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $35. Every day she works at her business from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m. She is requesting her second loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more firewood for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Wanu is 45 years old, divorced, and has three children: ages 24, 23 and 19. She also cares for three additional dependants. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members, Saumu and Simpe. Each woman also has her own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To buy more firewood for her business.

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Asha is a bites (maandazi) seller in the Melinne neighborhood of Zanzibar. She belongs to Mwanzo Mgumu group loan (Group code 2018). Every day she works at her business. She is requesting loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items (cooking oil and flour) for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to grow her business.

Asha is 39 years old, married, and has three children: ages 10, 9 and 8.

loans.use: To buy more items (cooking oil and flour) for her business.
